posts.title: Electricity and Magnetism
posts.excerpt: Electric Flux and Gauss’s LawThe concept of electric fluxToday’s whole new concept is Electric Flux. Suppose we have a electric field and we bring in that the electric field a surface, an open surface, and I carve this surface up in very small elements, each with size $dA$, a very teeny weeny area.
posts.text: Electric Flux and Gauss’s LawThe concept of electric fluxToday’s whole new concept is Electric Flux. Suppose we have a electric field and we bring in that the electric field a surface, an open surface, and I carve this surface up in very small elements, each with size $dA$, a very teeny weeny area. Then we take a direction as the normal $\hat{n}$. And at that location, the local electric field may be $\vec{E}$. Hence the electric flux $d\phi$ go through the little surface $dA$ is defined as the dot product of $E$ and the vector perpendicular to this element. $d\phi=\vec{E}\cdot\hat{n}\cdot dA=\vec{E}\cdot \vec{dA}=E\cdot dA\cdot cos(\theta)$ $\vec{dA}$ is a vector whose magnitude equals the area of the little surface and its direction is equivalent to the unit normal vector $\hat{n}$. And $\theta$ is the angle between those two vectors. Apparently, $d\phi$ is a scalar. The number can be larger, smaller than zero, and it can be zero. The SI unit of flux follows immediately from the definition $N\cdot C^{-1}\cdot m^2$. And in this case you can calculate the flux through the entire surface by doing an integral. $\phi=\int\vec{E}\cdot \vec{dA}$ Now we take a surface which is not open as the one we’ve talked above. It’s a completely closed surface like a potato or balloon. Here we notice by convention the normal to the surface, locally to the surface, is always from the inside of the surface to the outside world. It’s uniquely determined because it’s a close surface. For the open surface, which is not uniquely determined, we can abitrarily chose one but we could have flipped it over a hundred eighty degrees. And now we can calculate the total flux through the closed surface by doing a integral over the closed surface. $\phi =\oint \vec{E}\cdot \vec{dA}$ Also the flux $\phi$ is a scaler. It can be zero, positive or negative. If you think it as air, also flows out. If more flows out than flows in, then it’s positive. If more flows in than flows out, it’s negative. Now let’s calculate the flux for a small case where I have a point charge $Q_+$. And I take a sophere as its closed surface, which has radius $R$. Pick out a small element $\vec{dA}$, which is radially outward. Electric field $\vec{E}$ at that point is also radial. Since it’s sphere, the $\vec{E}$ in magnitude is everywhere the same, the distance is the same and the $\vec{dA}$ and $\vec{E}$ are parallel. The total flux through the spherical closed surface is simply the area of the surface of that sphere times $E_R$. $\phi =4\pi R^2E_R=4\pi R^2\frac{Q_+}{4\pi R^2\epsilon_0}=\frac{Q_+}{\epsilon_0}$ It’s independent of $R$, the size of the sphere. The flux is given by the charge which is at the center divided by $\epsilon_0$. Now if we had chosen some other shape, not a sphere, but I have dented it, it clear that would be the same like the air flows out as the case in sphere. The Gauss’s LawThe Gauss’s Law tells us that the electric flux going through the closed surface is sum of all charges inside the surface, that you may choose at any time you pick that surface, divided by $\epsilon_0$. $$\phi = \oint\vec{E}\cdot\vec{dA}=\frac{\sum{Q_{ins}}}{\epsilon_{0}} $$ This is the first of four equations of Maxwell. So electric flux through any closed surface is always the charge inside that closed surface divided by $\epsilon_0$. And if that flux happens to be zero, it means there is not net charge inside the closed surface. Gauss’s Law always holds no matter how wired the charge distribution inside that closed surface. But Gauss’s Law won’t help too much if you don’t have a situation whereby the charges are distributed in a very symmetric way. Gauss’s Law holds but it doesn’t do any good if you want to calculate the electric field. So the forms of symmetry will help a lot when you want to calculate the electric field. Example oneSpherical symmetrySpherical ball Now if we go to the spherical which is inside the shell and we know that $E$ is radially outwards apart from a plus or minus sign, apart from the fact that the angle between $\vec{dA}$ and $\vec{E}$, could either be zero degrees or one hundred eighty degrees. We know that the surface area times electric field is $4\pi r^2E=\frac{Q_{ins}}{\epsilon_0}$. There is no $Q_{ins}$ in this case, so the $E$ must be zero! It’s a nontrival and amazing result! Because it means anywhere as it is still in the shell no matter what radius you choose, the electric field equals zero. Notice that there is another simliar situation in thin shell which gravity is zero no matter any place you choose as long as it is inside the shell. In this case the symmetry arguments take into account that the charge is uniformly distributed. If the charge on the sphere had not been uniformaly distributed, we could not use the symmetry arguments, and therefore the electric field inside would in fact not have been zero. Now we go larger $r$ which is outside of the shell, we take the closed spherical surface and according to the equation provided by Gauss’s Law, we have $E=\frac{Q_+}{4\pi r^2\epsilon_0}$. We’ve seen this form before. If we had put all the charges right at the middle at the center, we would’ve gotten exactly the same answer. In other words, whether the charge is uniformly distriburted over a sphere, or whether the charge is , all of it, exactly right at the center of the sphere, that make no difference for $E$ as long as you’re outside the sphere. Gauss’s Law and Coulomb’s Law in a way are the same law, they both linked the electric field with the charge. The key is the electric force fall of as one over $r^2$. If it doesn’t fall off as one over $r^2$, then Gauss’s Law would not even hold. And the electric field inside the uniformly charged thin shell would not be zero. SO it’s the immediate consequence of the fact that electric forces fall off as one over $r^2$. ###Example two cylindrical symmetryA flat horizontal plane uniformly charged distributionsLet’s suppose a infinitely large flat, extraordinary large, uniformly charged distributed, and put a certain amount of charge density which calls $\sigma=\frac{Q}{A_{flat}}$. If we now pick a clever Gauss surface, the answer pops out very quickly that how does the electric field distribute. The answer is $\frac{Q_+}{2\epsilon_0}$ And this result is relatively to the linear size of that surface, if the flat is not infinitely large, then the $E$ would not go straight out of flat plane. You only have two contribution from those two planes, top and bottom. The configuration of a charged plane’s electric field Example twoTwo charged planes. Clearly that near the end of the two plane the $E\ne 0$, because you can’t use Gauss Law since it’s not symmetric at that area. Keywords of this article: Electric flux, Gauss’s law and the examples

posts.title: Electricity and  Magnetism
posts.text: Electric Field The conceptSuppose we have a charge $Q$ at a particular location and at another location $p$ have another test charge $q$. And there is a seperation bewteen the two which is $r$. Now we can introduce the idea of electric field for which we write the symbol capital $E$. $$\vec{E_p}=\frac{\vec{F}}{q},\quad \vec{F_p}=\frac{kQq}{r^2}\hat{r}$$ $$\vec{E_p}=\frac{kQ}{r^2}\hat{r}$$ Electric field (strength) $E$ is a vector. By convention, we say the $E$ is away from $Q$ if $Q$ is positive, if $Q$ is negative, the force is in the other direction, and therefore $E$ is in the other direction. And here is the key that the force in location $p$ depends on the test charge $q$ while electric field does not. The electric field is a representation for what happens around the charge plus $Q_+$. The graphical representationsHere is an example of a charge $+3$ and charge $-1$. The superposition principle of $Q_i$if we have several charges, the $E=\sum\limits_{i}E_{i}$ Is it obvious that superposition principle work? No. Does it works? Yes! How do we know it works? Because it’s consistent with all our experimental results. So we take the superposition principle for granted and that is acceptable. The electric field linesThe electric field lines are something imagined, but it shows some information of the electric field $E$ . Every tangent direction of the point which lies in the electric field demonstrate the direction of the force. And the number of lines show the electric strength of this area. The more, the stronger. The charge configurationThe force in the electric field is always like this $\vec{F}=q\vec{E}$. Doesn’t matter the $q$ is positive, then the same direction as $E$. If it is negative it will be the opposite direction as $E$. If $q$ is large, then the force will be large, and if it is small, then the force will be small. So the real secret behind the concept of an $E$ field is that you bring any charge at that location and you know what force acts at that point on that charge. Let’s see these two charges that one is $+3$ and the other is $-1$. If you put a test charge ,here we suppose it is positive, very close to the negative charge, then the force is oriented to the negative charge. It’s attractive force due to the effect of the two charges. But when you move that test charge very far away from the two charges, the situation changes. It’s equivalent to a single $+2$ charges. The force turn out to be a repulsion, which fall off at a speed of $r^2$, one over distance square. And in other cases which we can demonstrate, one postive charge and one negative charge fall off at a speed of $r^3$, one over the distance cubed. You can sort of think as these field lines if you want to imagine the configuration that the plus charges blow out air like a hairdryer, and that the minus suck in air like a vacuum cleaner. The induction and the dipole When we put a negatively charged rod nearly around two contacted metal balls, the electrons want to go away, so the right side ball will be negatively charged and at the same time the left side will be automatically postively charged. So when we seperate the two metal balls by insulated ways, the two balls become a dipole when we take them apart. Keywords of this article : Electric field ,the charge configuration, and the dipole

posts.title: Electricity and Magnetism
posts.excerpt: What holds our world together?As most of us had been crystal clear on this fact that the world is made up of atoms, the question we are actually asking is what is holding those atoms together.
posts.text: What holds our world together?As most of us had been crystal clear on this fact that the world is made up of atoms, the question we are actually asking is what is holding those atoms together. Well, what is holding them together are the nuclear forces, which we do not fully understand. So in other words, on nuclear scale $10^{-14}$ meters, very important are the nuclear forces; on an atomic scale up to thousands of kilmeters, it’s really electric forces that hold our world together. But on much larger scale, planets and the galaxy, it is gravity that holds our world together. Positive and negative chargesThe brief historyAlready in 600 hundred BC, it was known that if you rub amber that it can attract pieces of dry leaves. And the Greek word for amber is electron, so that’s where electricity got its name from. In the 16 centuries there were more substances known to do this. For instance glass and sulfur. It was also konwn and written that when people were bored at parties that the women would rub their amber jewelry and would touch frogs which then would start jumping of desperation, which people considered to be fun, not understanding what was actually happening to the amber nor what was happening to the frogs. In the 18 centuries it was discovered that there are two types of electricity: One if you rub glass and another if you rub rubber or amber for that matter, due to Benjamin Frankin without any knowledge of electrons and protonsw who introduced the idea that all substances are penetrated with what he called electric fluid, electric fire. And he stated it if you get too much of the fire the you’re positively charged and if you have a deficiency of that fire the you’re negatively charged. He introduced the sign convention and he decided that if you rub glass that is an excess of fire and be called that therefore positive. (You will see later why this choice, he had fifty percent chance, is extremely unfortunate but we have to live with it.) You cannot create charge, if you create plus then automatically create mius. Plus and plus repel each other, minus and minus repel each other. And plus and minus attract. Forces-Coulomb’s lawIf we take two charges and we use in general for charge the symbol Q. And Coulomb, the French physicist, who did a lot of research on this in the 18th~19th centuries actually. In the SI units we will use for the unit of charge the coulomb named after this great man. One coulomb charge is a horrendous amount if charge! More than you ever see in your life time. So let’s see the Coulombs’s Law, the force on charge number two due to one : $$\vec{F_{1,2}}=\frac{KQ_1Q_2}{r^2}\hat{r}_{1,2}$$ And the coulomb’s constant $K$ in SI units is $9\times10^9 $ $ N·m^2/c^2$, (for historical reasons, the $K$ is also equals $\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}$, this $\epsilon_0$ called the permittivity of free space), the $\hat{r}_{1,2}$ is the unit vector from 1 to 2. The charge of one proton, which is exactly the same as the charge of one electron, is approximately $1.6\times 10^{-19}$ C. The Coulomb Force and the GravityCompare them by computingNotice that there is a clear parallel with gravity. Newton’s law of gravity: $\vec{F_{1,2}}= - \frac{GM_1M_2}{r^2}\hat{r}_{1,2}$ $G=6.67259\times 10^{-11}$ $ N·m²/kg²$ is the gravitational constant. Comparing electricity with gravity, you’ll see that electric forces are way more powerful than gravitational forces Let’s caculate the magnitude of the forces by taking two protons, which are seperated by a distance $d$. $F_{e}=\frac{KQQ}{d^2}=\frac{9 \times 10^9 \times (1.6\times 10^{-19})^2}{d^2}$ $F_g=\frac{Gmm}{d^2}=\frac{6.67 \times 10^{-11}\times(1.7\times 10^{-27})^2}{d^2}$ $\frac{F_e}{F_g}\approx36$ So the electric force is 36 orders of magnitude more potent than the gravitational attraction! The nuclear forcesThe nucleus has a size of about $10^{-14}$ meters, and the atom itself is about ten thousand times larger. The cloud of electrons which is about $10^{-10}$ meters. Let’s think about $a_p=\frac{F_{electricity}}{M_P}$ If you make $d=10^{-14} $ $m^2$, and you calculate the ratio you will find it is 26 orders of magnitude higher than the graviton acceleration on the earth. So you wonder what the hell holds the nucleus together. If there is such a tremendous force on these protons. Well thats nuclear forces, which we do not fully understand yet. The PolarizationsConductors have a small fraction of their electrons which are not bound to atoms but which we can freely move around in the conductor. That’s a characteristic for a conductor, for metals. While that’s not the case with nonconductors there the all electrons are fixed to individual atoms. The electrons want to be attracted by positive charges. When you use a conductor approaching positive charges, some of (very subtle) these electrons will move to the closer side to the positive charges. Then the closer side is negative and the other side is positive. This process we call induction. It’s sort of a polarization. And by the way, in the nonconductors’ cases, the things described above are still the same, but much more subtle. Keywords of this article : Electric charges , Forces-Coulomb’s law and Polarizations

posts.title: Hello World !
posts.excerpt: 似乎任何与代码相关的东西都离不开 Hello World ！这句神奇咒语，于是我便借此作为本篇标题，寓意是啥我也不知道。
posts.text: 似乎任何与代码相关的东西都离不开 Hello World ！这句神奇咒语，于是我便借此作为本篇标题，寓意是啥我也不知道。 很高兴你能来到我的个人博客! 这是我的个人博客，可以看出这是基于GitHub Pages和 Hexo的静态网页的博客（没啥技术含量，但是愚蠢的DJ到现在还没完全搞明白其中的种种），搭建这个博客的时候遇到了不少莫名其妙的问题，大多也被我莫名其妙地解决了-/0-0/！～ 从最初的搞定一直网页404，到最后搭建完成还是略有所获。我希望能写下并总结一些学习生活上的种种，我想完全是可以代替日记本的。目前没啥文字，没想着去租一个好看好记的域名，页面也还有不足，这只是个开始，就像法拉第[Faraday]曾经驳斥过：“一个刚出生的婴儿又有什么用呢？” 于是这就成了我的第一篇Blog起因搭建这个博客我是没有细想过的，直到运动会期间我的好友给了我这个idea，我觉得可还行，试着就做了（没事喜欢折腾，但实在也没啥技术含量） 作用我的个人博客我想把它用于学习，记录，分享。这博客能写出文字，代码，还能渲染出公式（LaTeX），还有点音乐（虽然有不足ಠ_ಠ）等，可以干的东西应该不少。这类博客网上也不少，应该还是能有所获。 不足现在这个博客还没达到我心里想要的效果，比如背景图还没有选（没找到合适的壁纸），网易云的音乐插件只能在一个页面播放（不支持全局播放，毕竟是静态网页，估计是没办法解决了），主题还是依靠别人写的框架（日后我再研究研究自己写吧），最重要的是，还没啥文字在里面。 待做日后我等我把东西写多了（估计也会和朋友一起写），应该会去找马云dad租个域名，日后说不定也会加上评论功能（点赞就算了。。），可以看出这篇文章还没有图片，因为我还没学会如何批量上传图床并恰当应用，日后解决。
